coredata.dc:title: The water dimer: Theory versus experiment
coredata.dc:creator: Newton, Marshall D.
Kestner, Neil R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Equilibrium O…O separations (r e) and bond energies (D e) are calculated for the water dimer, with electron correlation included at the Møller—Plesset (MP2 or MP3) level. Inclusion of corrections for basis set superposition error allows the experimental data for r e and D e to be bracketed. The r e for the dimer is significantly larger than the mean O…O distance in liquid water.

Inclusion of corrections for basis set superposition error allows the experimental data for r, and De to be bracketed. There for tile dinner is significantly larger than the mean 0 ... 0 distance in liquid water. The water dieter (1._' 1 is of considerable theoretical interest per se as a prototype for the 0li...O hydrogen hand [ -- 1 1 1 and also as a point of reference in connection with effective pair potentials suitable for modelling liquid water 112--151 and ice [16-1o].1Vltfe calculated equilibrium O_..O separations (re) at the nearI lartree--Fock (I IF) level ('_' 9S-3.0'_' A) [6,5,1 1 ] arc close to tile microwave rtl value (_'.9S A). recent calculations including electron correlation (CI) have for the t110Si part yielded substantially slnallerre values (2.86 Q_' :1) [6.`).101 which are actually rather close to the r value corresponding: to the peak in the 0 ... 0 pair distribution function for liquid water (?.S5 A) [19]. 1=intherntore. one of the CI potential energy functions (tile \1fl' potential based oil intermolecular Cl, with re = _'. A) 191 has been quite effective in simulating the properties of liquid water [ 1?,1 31. These results are surprising sine one would expect significant difference: between actual and effective dinler potentials dtte to than y-body effects. including cooperative enhancement of multiple sequential hydrogen bonding 1-1.5.'1 . In addition, the discrepancy with respect to t fir larger microwave r(I value remains, although it has heell su~,Oested that thermal (15] or zero-point [10] averaging over tile anharntonic 0 ... 0 potential curve might account for tile apparently large differences between re and r(1. In fact. thermal effects in the micro- Pennattent address: Department of Chemistry. Louisiana State University. Baton Rouge. Louisiana 7(18113. USA- wave experiment appear very unlikely [1], and model calculations based on zero-point motion (see below) indicate that anltamtonicity yields a shift of only 0.02 A. Here we focus on an important systematic defect of finite basis set calculations known as basis set superposition error (BSSE) [6,9,10,20-27] and present a variety of new ab initio results (table 1) which allow a resolution of the problems raised above and which demonstrate that the calculated and experimental results for the free dieter are in reasonable agreement when proper account is made for the BSSE effect. The latter is thought to be of particular importance in two rather different situations: first. the case of minimal or other small basis sets [21,23,27] and second, the case of very weak interactions (e a., (He)2 or (H-))2) [22. 24,25] . The magnitude of the BSSE effect is usually defined by the so-called counterpoise correction (CC) [20] which is the difference between the total energy of the relevant reference subunits (water monomers here) calculated at infinite separation and that in which each monomer is assigned the orbital basis set of tile entire complex at the intermolecular geometry of interest. An appreciable CC term was found in a previous large-scale Cl calculation for the water dimer, but it was assumed to provide only a gross overestimate of the proper correction term and no attempt was made to modify the potential energy curve even though the CC terms exhibited a pronounced r dependence [6]. Table 1 shows 200 (MP-1 and MP3) that they all yield similar pattems, and the corrected and uncorrected quantities may be taken as reasonable upper and lower bounds for re and De. Furthermore, these calculated bounds more or less symmetrically bracket the experimental values, especially in the case of the best orbital basis set (MCY'). 77tus theory and experiment for the free dimer can be considered to be in satisfactory agreement with respect to the magnitude of re and De, and re for the free dieter is found as expected (see above) to be significantly greater than the value of r associated with the peak in the liquid pair correlation function [191. It therefore appears likely that any effective potential for liquid water based on the properly calculated free dieter potential would also require inclusion of significant threebody contributions (i.e. trinlers). It is also clear that future efforts to obtain accurate ab initio intermolecular potentials will require systematic basis set studies aimed at bringing BSSE effects under control at the CI level. head.ce:title: The water dimer: Theory versus experiment

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New, York 11973, USA

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: Permanent address: Department of Chemistry, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, Louisiana 70803, USA.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Equilibrium O…O separations (r e) and bond energies (D e) are calculated for the water dimer, with electron correlation included at the Møller—Plesset (MP2 or MP3) level. Inclusion of corrections for basis set superposition error allows the experimental data for r e and D e to be bracketed. The r e for the dimer is significantly larger than the mean O…O distance in liquid water.
